title: Re-framing service delivery, professional practices and professional identities in UK careers work
abstractText:
Careers guidance has been practised in the UK, in one form or another and with various labels, for about a century, with services required to address different social and political priorities. Against a turbulent policy background, the profession of careers guidance is, once again, is at a crossroads.

A recent governmental Task Force Report on the Careers Profession (October, 2010) crystallises fundamental challenges for careers guidance related to its fragmentation; the loss of occupational identity in its practitioners; the inability to recruit and retain a diverse, high calibre workforce; and the consequent difficulties in delivering professional practice of a consistently high standard that integrates research with theory. Services are, once again, under review across all four home countries of the UK.
The aims of this seminar series were to:

  • explore the professional identities of UK careers guidance and careers practitioners
  • foster dialogue amongst key stakeholders
  • contribute to policy discussions about the future shape of services and building workforce capacity.

The series comprised 6 one-day seminars, based at universities across the four home countries and in the Irish Republic. Seminars were highly interactive, to foster interdisciplinary and inter-sectoral dialogue, using methods to maximise participant engagement.
